      <tr>
        <td id="L18" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="18"></td>
        <td id="LC18" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mb">**Objective**</span>: The objective of this analysis is to answer two questions about severe weather events:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L19" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="19"></td>
        <td id="LC19" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L20" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="20"></td>
        <td id="LC20" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> Across the United States, which types of events (as indicated in the <span class="pl-c1">`EVTYPE`</span> variable) are most harmful with respect to population health? </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L21" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="21"></td>
        <td id="LC21" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> Across the United States, which types of events have the greatest economic consequences?</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L22" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="22"></td>
        <td id="LC22" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L23" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="23"></td>
        <td id="LC23" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mb">**Analysis**</span>: This analysis uses a subset of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration&#39;s (NOAA) Storm Database, limited to events in the US from 1996-2011. Impacts on human health are measured as the total fatalities and injuries as a result of severe weather, and economic consequences as the total costs of property and crop damage.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L24" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="24"></td>
        <td id="LC24" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L25" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="25"></td>
        <td id="LC25" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mb">**Results**</span>: Results show that from 1996-2011 excessive heat accounts for the greatest number of fatalies, tornados for injuries, and floods for economic costs.</td>

        <td id="LC74" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The events in the database start in 1950 and end in November 2011. Earlier records only report tornados, thunderstorm wind, and hail. [<span class="pl-e">Records beginning from January 1996 report more comprehensive severe weather event types and are considered more complete</span>](https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:KW1Sg00sXMsJ:https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/details.jsp+&amp;cd=2&amp;hl=en&amp;ct=clnk&amp;gl=ca&amp;client=safari). We restrict the analysis to weather events from January 1996 and onwards to prevent bias from earlier records limited only to tornados, thunderstorm wind, and hail events.</td>

        <td id="LC195" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Across the United States from 1996 to 2011, out of all severe weather events, excessive heat caused the greatest number of fatalities. Excessive heat accounts for <span class="pl-c1">`20.6%`</span> of all severe weather<span class="pl-c1">&amp;ndash;</span>related fatalities (<span class="pl-c1">`1,787`</span> of <span class="pl-c1">`8,732`</span>), followed closely by tornados, <span class="pl-c1">`17.3%`</span>. However, tornados account for the greatest number of injuries by far: <span class="pl-c1">`42.2%`</span> of all severe weather<span class="pl-c1">&amp;ndash;</span>related injuries (<span class="pl-c1">`20,667`</span> of <span class="pl-c1">`48,917`</span>).</td>

        <td id="L243" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="243"></td>
        <td id="LC243" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Across the United States from 1996 to 2011, floods caused the greatest economic damage (i.e. total costs of property and crop damages). Floods and hurricanes are the only severe weather events with an excess of <span class="pl-c1">`$50-billion`</span> in economic damages. However, floods are far more costly, resulting in a total of <span class="pl-c1">`$144-billion`</span> in economic damages, compared to hurricanes, totalling <span class="pl-c1">`$82-billion`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
